content: Indeed, I think you point to the right issue: there's no functionality in Lean that allows you to be parametric in declarations in the correct way that ML-ish functors would allow you to be. Typeclasses come close, but you can't write down which implicits are allowed to differ: you can't do to_additive with them because there's no way to say "let X be either an add_comm_monoid or a comm_monoid and Y the same (but not X additive and Y multiplicative)". Or we'd have to completely unbundle the data from the proofs, but then you lose the head symbols as a result.

So I think the best way with the current architecture of Lean is duplicating the mem_carrier, ext, copy parts of set_like, either manually or programmatically. But that's just a constant amount of work per subobject, and what I'm interested in is that we have a multiplicative amount of duplication of lemmas of the form subfoo.bar_mem: (number of subobject types extending subfoo) √ó (number of operations closed under subfoo): currently we (incompletely and ad-hoc) copy over each of these per subobject type extending subfoo. And for that issue typeclasses can be useful.

More specifically, for each

structure subfoo (Œ± : Type*) [foo Œ±] :=
(carrier : set Œ±)
(op_mem' : ‚àÄ {x}, x ‚àà carrier ‚Üí foo.op x ‚àà carrier)

we create a

class subfoo_class (S : Type*) (Œ± : out_param Type*) [foo Œ±]
  extends set_like S Œ± :=
(op_mem : ‚àÄ {s : S} {x}, x ‚àà s ‚Üí foo.op x ‚àà s

and then every subobject coercible to a subfoo can get an instance of subfoo_class.

Since the class is parametrized only by types and other instances, we don't have any issues with equalities requiring transport of instances. We keep the head symbols ‚àà and (coe : subfoo Œ± ‚Üí set Œ±) from the bundled subobjects so no issues with rw/simp. And no more duplication of _mem lemmas: for each operation op‚ÇÇ that subfoos are closed under, we can define op‚ÇÇ_mem as follows:

lemma op‚ÇÇ_mem {S Œ± : Type*} [foo Œ±] [subfoo_class S Œ±] {s : S}
  {x y : Œ±} (hx : x ‚àà s) (hy : y ‚àà s) : op‚ÇÇ x y ‚àà s :=
sorry

And for each structure subbar Œ± extends subfoo Œ± with a corresponding subfoo_class (subbar Œ±) Œ± instance gets immediate access to op‚ÇÇ_mem, no need for hacks like subbar.to_subfoo.op‚ÇÇ_mem.

Indeed, looking at the defeq trace, the issue is really that the inference for the has_zero Œ≤ instance will only be attempted after the defeq check for the instance to be applied, measurable.subtype.closed_under_zero. So it can't figure out semiring.zero =?= @has_zero.zero Œ≤ ?. Maybe that's changed in Lean 4 now that the elaborator can postpone goals, but here the only way I can find to force the has_zero Œ≤ instance to be there already is through including it in one of the types.
(Or you can make it an out_param I guess, but that brings with it a whole other host of issues!)
